displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: If they’re available. Patient: I don’t think there’s really any hard dates that we need to have or need to work around- Family Member: I can’t think of any. Patient: in the next month or two. Well, you’ll scheduled to be the driver. Family Member: No. Oh, no it won’t. I mean they told multiple times they’ll work with me and so that is not lip service. Patient: Larry said he’d be willing to, as long as, he’s thinking, two to three hours. Or if he can get me here, somebody will get me out. Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_,

Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. And when do we expect to leave your dad’s house? Patient: I think we’re supposed to be getting the keys to the house we’re purchasing next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But that doesn’t mean we’re moving in next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re probably going to have some work done. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And stay at dad’s until it’s all done. Doctor: So it might be a couple of months.

Patient: But, okay, okay. Doctor: You’ll still do… Patient: That’s my only concern because because whoever called to schedule it said R__ you can do it before the holiday or do it afterward. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: We’ve got family coming and stuff like that too so… Doctor: So I think you should just do it after you know you finish radiation June eighth so that’s we’re covered and everything is great, your counts are fine. So you know you’re anemic is still at, your hemoglobin is still at eight point nine. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which is great. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Post radiation… Patient: So it came up then and just… Doctor: Yeah you’re fine.

Patient: Well then you mentioned other supplements. Doctor: Right. I think your standard basic multivitamin, it’s a thumbs up. Because that’s just sort of your regular, you know, recommended daily allowance, your recommended daily intake, that’s no problem. But if you start taking high doses of things, we just don’t know what it’s going to do. Family Member: What is that black pill you’re taking? Patient: That’s the macular- Family Member: For macular degeneration? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: It’s a it’s for it’s for your eyes? Patient: Yes. Taking daily for the eyes. Family Member: I don’t know if it’s good to take that either. Is it? Would it be? Doctor: I don’t know. I don’t know what the black pill is. Family Member: Well, it’s a capsule, it’s a capsule and it’s got that- Patient: Gel cap.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh Doctor: But I think the way back when CAT scan you had some. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay but they were very small and they may not be something at all significant. So you know I think your last CAT scan again barely showed anything Patient: Right. Doctor: so I don’t think we need to worry about those. But doing that Xofigo treatment would absolutely be another valid option if you don’t want to do chemotherapy. So the good news is that you have some options for standard treatment and you have some options for clinical trials. So you know either way we have options. I’m just reluctant to switch things if the scans don’t show us any change. Family Member 2: Right, right.

Patient: Ahhhh I leave this Wednesday and I come back on the fifteenth of February. That is negotiable. Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I need to hop a plane and come back here… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …that is not a problem. Doctor: And you have been off the Casodex now for a couple weeks? Patient: By whenever yeah, Doctor: Something like that, okay. Patient: two weeks ago today. Doctor: Yeah, okay. Let me give you the brief summary of what I think is happening because I know you like it itemized so we have a plan. One, your PSA’s going up but not unexpected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because we talked about how Provenge just doesn’t touch that PSA.

Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

displayed_text: Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: -you’re coming back. Call me a little hyper-anal. Doctor: Yes. Let’s do that. Doctor: I am. Good plan. Right? Plus it’ll keep you more on track if you know that you have to come in and we check your sugars and yeppers. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of-

Family Member: Okay. Patient: Follow-up question here to Doctor: You could do either way. Family Member: Yeah. And how long are you there when you go get your radiation? Doctor: About a half an hour total. So you do it on your way to work or on the way home. Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes? Doctor: Just let us know. Patient: Okay. It won’t take long; I just want to absorb everything. Then I get back. Okay. Doctor: Um, R___ do you have any other questions? Family Member 1: Just the sequence of things. The hormone therapy and the chemo therapy and Zytiga. Are they all started at the same time? Doctor: Uh, pretty much, yeah. Um and we could start the hormone shot any time. Patient: I’m scheduled.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you have any other questions that arise immediately that you want to discuss? Patient: Uh, and you may not be able to are you gonna be able to check when Doctor: Yeah so that’s a good question. So um there’s an easy answer to that and there’s a more easy answer to that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The easy answer is if you ever develop symptoms from your cancer. For example, if the cancer has spread to your bone or if the cancer in the lymph node causing a blood obstruction. stop the Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: How, how long have you been home now? Patient: Two days or- Family Member: Three days. Doctor: From S___’s. Yes. So I, I need you to be two weeks, walking around, not back in the hospital, fully recovered- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Until we can go and talk about that. No rush. Plus your next shot I think is April fourth. So we may uh, you know, we’ll work on that, but you may even be, you come in at the same time, and we can use that same visit. So I’ll look at that. Okay? Any questions? Patient: I didn’t know that you - So that’s what I had? I had cancer, I mean, uh, I had pneumonia and-? Doctor: Pneumonia and the flu. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: The flu? Yeah. That’s what I had before. Doctor: Yeah. I think that’s what happened when I talked to your doctor. They were for sure about pneumonia. They were waiting on the flu results at the time. But I think they treated you like you had the flu, anyway, so. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, today, we’ve got to sort of talk about what next. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I just reviewed, again, all the scans from a month ago or so. So really what we see in you is all of the disease seems to be in the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you don’t have any really anything in lymph nodes, or liver, or lung, which is, you know, good and bad. Uh, the bad part of it is, you know, it’s hard to kind of get a good sense of how things work in the bone because the scans we do are, uh, mostly telling us new spots in the bone. But they, we can’t really measure things getting bigger or smaller. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So here are the orders themselves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Again, this should have been submitted to LabCorp. But if you don’t have them, instead of calling over and having to get it faxed, you can hold onto that. Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you, sir. Doctor: I will see you both in January. Patient: In January and then Doctor: The date we picked, it was the seventeenth. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: The timing, the timing and the schedule . Okay, so have a nice holiday season. Patient: Okay, you, too. Have a safe trip. Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see both of you.

Family Member: That’s all right. (doors closing) Patient: They are? Good. Family Member: you’re eating. Doctor: I know about one again. Patient: The first time I went that was at the beginning, just like taking a shot, a few days after that I was throwing up every day for four days. And I talked to your assistant on email, and he said to go to emergency, and so we went and the problem was I wasn’t urinating properly. So they put a catheter in. Doctor: Let me stop you one second. Let’s, let me review some of the paperwork – Patient: Sure. So you can concentrate. Doctor: So uh you’re still taking the Bicalutamide or have you finished that -- the Casodex? Patient: What is that? Doctor: Uh what the pill that you took two weeks before I gave you the shot. Family Member: Yes, that’s done. The hormone - Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s -
